glossary/glossary.title: Glossary
glossary/glossary.description: Welcome to the SpecWeave Technical Glossary! This comprehensive reference explains all technical terms used in enterprise software development, with practical examples and diagrams.

glossary/index-by-category.title: Glossary by Category
glossary/index-by-category.description: Explore technical terms organized by related concepts.

glossary/terms/ac-id.title: AC-ID (Acceptance Criteria Identifier)
glossary/terms/ac-id.description: AC-ID is a unique identifier for acceptance criteria that enables complete traceability from specifications through implementation to tests. The format AC-US-{number} creates an unbroken chain of accountability ensuring every requirement is implemented and tested.

glossary/terms/acceptance-criteria.title: Acceptance Criteria (AC)
glossary/terms/acceptance-criteria.description: Acceptance Criteria (AC) are specific, testable conditions that define when a user story is considered complete. Each criterion must be measurable, unambiguous, and verifiable through testing. In SpecWeave, acceptance criteria use AC-IDs for complete traceability from requirements through implementation to tests.

glossary/terms/bdd.title: BDD (Behavior-Driven Development)
glossary/terms/bdd.description: Behavior-Driven Development (BDD) is a software development methodology that focuses on describing the behavior of a system from the user's perspective using natural language. BDD extends TDD by emphasizing collaboration between developers, QA, and business stakeholders.

glossary/terms/bidirectional-sync.title: Bidirectional Sync
glossary/terms/bidirectional-sync.description: ‚ö†Ô∏è DEPRECATED as of v0.24.0: The "bidirectional sync" terminology has been replaced with the Three-Permission Architecture for more granular control.

glossary/terms/content-classification.title: Content Classification
glossary/terms/content-classification.description: Content Classification is SpecWeave's automatic system for categorizing documentation into nine distinct types (user stories, NFRs, architecture, ADRs, operations, delivery, strategy, governance, overview). Each category has specific detection patterns, confidence scoring, and target folders for intelligent organization.

glossary/terms/cross-linking.title: Cross-Linking
glossary/terms/cross-linking.description: Cross-Linking is SpecWeave's automatic system for generating bidirectional links between related documents. It creates four types of relationships (implements, references, defined-in, related-to) with relative path resolution and "Related Documents" sections in Markdown.

glossary/terms/docusaurus-frontmatter.title: Docusaurus Frontmatter
glossary/terms/docusaurus-frontmatter.description: Docusaurus Frontmatter is YAML metadata at the top of Markdown files that provides context for Docusaurus static site generation and LLM understanding. SpecWeave's intelligent living docs sync automatically generates rich frontmatter with standard fields (id, title, sidebar_label, description, tags) and SpecWeave-specific fields (project, category, increment, status).

glossary/terms/fda.title: FDA (Food and Drug Administration) - Medical Device Software Regulations

glossary/terms/hipaa.title: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)

glossary/terms/hooks.title: Hooks
glossary/terms/hooks.description: Hooks are automated scripts that execute at specific lifecycle events in SpecWeave. They enable automatic documentation sync, external tool updates, and workflow automation without manual intervention.

glossary/terms/increments.title: Increments
glossary/terms/increments.description: An Increment is a focused unit of work in SpecWeave that represents a complete, shippable slice of functionality. Each increment contains a specification, implementation plan, and task checklist with embedded tests. Increments are the fundamental building block of SpecWeave's development workflow.

glossary/terms/integration-testing.title: Integration Testing
glossary/terms/integration-testing.description: Integration Testing validates that different components or systems work correctly together. Unlike unit tests that isolate individual functions, integration tests verify the interactions between multiple units, services, or external systems.

glossary/terms/intelligent-living-docs-s.title: Intelligent Living Docs Sync
glossary/terms/intelligent-living-docs-s.description: Intelligent Living Docs Sync is SpecWeave's advanced synchronization system that automatically parses, classifies, and distributes increment specifications into organized, cross-linked documentation. Unlike simple mode (one file ‚Üí one file), intelligent mode uses a 9-category classification system with project detection, Docusaurus frontmatter generation, and automatic cross-linking.

glossary/terms/living-docs.title: Living Documentation
glossary/terms/living-docs.description: Living Documentation is documentation that stays automatically synchronized with your codebase and project state. Unlike traditional static documentation that becomes outdated, living docs are updated automatically through hooks, automation, and bidirectional sync with external systems.

glossary/terms/playwright.title: Playwright
glossary/terms/playwright.description: Playwright is a modern end-to-end (E2E) testing framework for web applications that enables reliable testing across all modern browsers (Chromium, Firefox, WebKit). Created by Microsoft, Playwright provides a powerful API for browser automation, testing, and web scraping.

glossary/terms/profile-based-sync.title: Profile-Based Sync
glossary/terms/profile-based-sync.description: Profile-Based Sync is SpecWeave's architecture for syncing increments to unlimited external repositories (GitHub, JIRA, Azure DevOps) with intelligent rate limiting, time range filtering, and project-specific configuration. Each sync profile defines how to connect to an external system, with support for multiple profiles per provider.

glossary/terms/project-detection.title: Project Detection
glossary/terms/project-detection.description: Project Detection is SpecWeave's automatic system for identifying which project (backend, frontend, mobile, etc.) a piece of content belongs to. It uses a multi-signal scoring algorithm with frontmatter fields, increment IDs, team names, keywords, and tech stack detection to achieve 70%+ accuracy.

glossary/terms/role-orchestrator.title: Role Orchestrator
glossary/terms/role-orchestrator.description: Role Orchestrator is SpecWeave's multi-agent coordination system that sequences specialized AI agents (PM, Architect, Tech Lead, QA, DevOps) to work together on complex tasks.

glossary/terms/skills-vs-agents.title: Skills vs Agents
glossary/terms/skills-vs-agents.description: SpecWeave uses two types of AI components: Skills (auto-activating knowledge) and Agents (explicitly invoked workers). Understanding the difference is crucial for effective use.

glossary/terms/source-of-truth.title: Source of Truth
glossary/terms/source-of-truth.description: Source of Truth is the single, authoritative location for data. In SpecWeave's architecture, .specweave/ is the source of truth for content (user stories, specs, architecture), while external tools (GitHub, JIRA, ADO) are sources of truth for status (issue state, labels, assignees). This split architecture prevents conflicts and ensures clarity.

glossary/terms/specs.title: Specifications (Specs)
glossary/terms/specs.description: A Specification (Spec) is a comprehensive document that defines WHAT needs to be built, including user stories, acceptance criteria, business rationale, and success metrics. In SpecWeave, specs exist in TWO locations: permanent living docs (complete feature-level knowledge base) and temporary increment specs (focused implementation tracker).

glossary/terms/strategic-init.title: Strategic Init
glossary/terms/strategic-init.description: Strategic Init is SpecWeave's AI-powered project initialization that guides you through 6 research phases to determine optimal architecture, compliance requirements, team sizing, and cost estimates.

glossary/terms/tdd.title: TDD (Test-Driven Development)
glossary/terms/tdd.description: Test-Driven Development (TDD) is a software development methodology where tests are written before the implementation code. The developer writes a failing test, then writes the minimum code to pass the test, and finally refactors the code while keeping tests passing.

glossary/terms/test-coverage.title: Test Coverage
glossary/terms/test-coverage.description: Test Coverage measures the percentage of your code that is executed by automated tests. It helps identify untested code paths and assess the completeness of your test suite.

glossary/terms/test-pyramid.title: Test Pyramid
glossary/terms/test-pyramid.description: The Test Pyramid is a testing strategy that defines the ideal distribution of test types in a software project. It recommends having many unit tests, some integration tests, and few end-to-end tests to achieve optimal test coverage, speed, and reliability.

glossary/terms/three-permission-architec.title: Three-Permission Architecture
glossary/terms/three-permission-architec.description: Three-Permission Architecture replaces the old "bidirectional sync" binary flag with granular control over three distinct sync operations.

glossary/terms/unit-testing.title: Unit Testing
glossary/terms/unit-testing.description: Unit Testing is a software testing methodology that tests individual units of code (functions, methods, classes) in isolation from the rest of the system. Unit tests verify that each unit works correctly on its own, independent of external dependencies.

glossary/terms/user-stories.title: User Stories
glossary/terms/user-stories.description: A User Story is a concise, user-focused description of a feature or requirement written from the perspective of the end user. User stories follow the format: "As a [user type], I want [goal], so that [benefit]". They serve as the primary unit of requirements in SpecWeave and are the foundation for implementation planning.

glossary/terms/wip-limits.title: WIP Limits (Work In Progress)
glossary/terms/wip-limits.description: WIP Limits restrict the number of active increments to maximize focus and productivity. SpecWeave defaults to ONE active increment based on research showing single-tasking produces 100% productivity while multi-tasking reduces productivity by 20-40% due to context switching costs.

guides/autonomous-execution.title: Autonomous Execution Guide
guides/autonomous-execution.description: Learn how to use SpecWeave's autonomous execution mode (/sw:auto) to work hands-free until all tasks are complete.

guides/best-practices.title: Best Practices for SpecWeave with Claude Code
guides/best-practices.description: This guide combines SpecWeave's spec-driven methodology with Claude Code's best practices to maximize your productivity.

guides/compliance-standards.title: Compliance Standards Reference
guides/compliance-standards.description: Complete Guide to 30+ Compliance Standards Supported by SpecWeave Strategic Init

guides/core-concepts/background-jobs.title: Background Jobs
guides/core-concepts/background-jobs.description: SpecWeave's Background Jobs System enables long-running operations to continue even after you close Claude. This is essential for enterprise workflows with thousands of repositories and tens of thousands of work items.

guides/core-concepts/living-documentatio.title: Living Documentation
guides/core-concepts/living-documentatio.description: Living documentation is documentation that automatically stays synchronized with your code‚Äîno manual updates, no drift, always current.

guides/core-concepts/what-is-an-incremen.title: What is an Increment?
guides/core-concepts/what-is-an-incremen.description: An increment is SpecWeave's fundamental unit of work‚Äîa complete, self-contained feature with specifications, architecture, implementation plan, and tests.

guides/cost-optimization.description: Save 60-70% on AI costs with SpecWeave's intelligent model selection

workflows/overview.description: SpecWeave provides clear, repeatable workflows for every phase of software development‚Äîfrom initial concept to production deployment.

workflows/planning.description: The planning phase transforms a feature idea into a complete, executable implementation plan with specifications, architecture, tasks, and tests.
